p: HIV Attachment and Entry: Pursuing a Challenging Target

h3._: HIV-1 Entry: The First Step in the HIV-1 Life Cycle

li: The molecular machine that is at the core of HIV entry is called the HIV envelope (Env) trimer, which is placed at the surface of virus particles

h3._: Key Viral Protein for HIV Entry

li: After the HIV virus attaches to CD4, the membrane of the virus and the host's cell surface membrane need to fuse
After the fusion process, the genetic material from the virus enters the host cell

h3._: HIV-1 Immune Pressure and Evasion

li: Most viruses are not subject to huge immune pressure during the entry process
During the chronic phase of HIV infection, very high levels of antibody are present
These antibodies are trying to recognize the virus surface, where the only viral protein is the HIV Env trimer
The HIV Env trimer has evolved many ways to evade the antibody attack, differentiating itself from other viruses

h3._: Overall Outline of Type 1 Fusion Mechanism of HIV-1 Entry Resolved 20 Years Ago

li: Many viruses like influenza and Ebola use the same mechanism of entry, which is called a type 1 fusion mechanism
At the very start of the HIV entry process, the glycoprotein (gp)160 protein is cleaved into the exterior gp120 protein and the transmembrane gp41 protein, which is the fusion machine

li._: These molecules bind to CD4 and the co-receptor, and this process triggers what is called a pre-hairpin intermediate, whereby part of the fusion machinery, called the fusion peptide, is thrown into the target cell membrane

li: Small molecule inhibitors currently under investigation can inhibit this step and the subsequent conformational changes
If inhibition does not take place, the pre-hairpin intermediate turns into a hairpin, which then fuses membranes in a process that is not yet entirely known
Ultimately, the process ends with postfusion structures and the fusion of the viral membrane with the target cell membrane

h3._: HIV-1 Env Entry Pathway Contains Additional Prefusion States

li: The Env trimer has several conformational states that it reaches in order to evade immune recognition

h3._: Understand Entry and Immune Evasion with Atomic-Level Insights

li: The different structural states of the HIV entry process have been studied at the atomic level in an effort to design therapeutic products for HIV treatment

h3._: Understand Entry and Immune Evasion with Atomic-Level Insights (cont)
Link Ligand-Induced States to smFRET Measurements
smFRET Tags In V1-V4 Sample Conformational Flexibility of HIV-1 Env Trimer on Infectious Virus
Functional Env Trimer Transitions Between 3 Prefusion Conformation States

li: Viruses such as influenza or Ebola have a single prefusion conformation state
With HIV, the Env trimer transitions between different states

h3._: State 1 Was Preferentially Recognized by Most Broadly Neutralizing Antibodies

li: Adding certain antibodies will force the Env molecule into a particular state
This effect occurs with many antibodies, and also with small molecules such as temsavir (formerly BMS-626529)
Both laboratory-adapted virus and primary isolate show similar responses, meaning that this process is a "general" way that the HIV Env trimer uses to enter cells

h3._: Determination of Env Trimer Structure Used 2 Antibodies For Crystallization
Initial Interaction of CD4 With the HIV-1 Env Trimer
Measurement of smFRET Directly on Soluble Env Trimers

li._: The initial single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (smFRET) measurements were performed on the surface of the infectious virus

li: The crystal structures are actually solubilized protein
An alternative way to study these structures is to take the solubilized protein, the trimer, place the smFRET tags, attach these to a glass slide, and look at the smFRET measurements

h3._: Insights on Structure of Env Trimers
Structural Transformation: State 2 to State 3
Inhibitors That Bind to States 1 and 2 Neutralize Primary Isolates; Those That Only Bind State 3 Often Do Not

li: The way HIV evades the immune system is by staying in state 1 and state 2, and only roughly transitioning to state 3 when it needs to enter the host cell
Therefore, the best entry inhibitors are those that can bind to state 1 and state 2

h3._: Entry Inhibitors and Targets
Fostemsavir (BMS-663068)

li: The small molecule temsavir is a very potent attachment inhibitor; however, it has poor biological activity due to its hydrophobic nature
Addition of a methyl phosphate to the structure results in the small molecule called fostemsavir (BMS-663068), which has very good bioavailability

h3._: Fostemsavir: BRIGHTE Phase 3 Study
Crystal Structures of HIV-1-Env Trimer With BMS-378806 and Its Derivative, Temsavir
Lattice-Chaperone Strategy: Mutations for Improvement
Summary: Chaperone Mutations for Improvement

li: Approximately twice as much information (vs what was previously available) is obtained by using the lattice-chaperone strategy
Structures can now be read at about 3 Å

h3._: New Lattice Appears to Be Improved
New Crystal Allows for the Determination of Structures With Trimers From Diverse HIV-1 Strains

li: New lattice also allows researchers to look for HIV-1 variability

The crystal lattice currently available is composed purely of antibodies binding to the Env trimer; with these in place, crystals can be formed using all sorts of different trimers captured within the crystal lattice
This technique has allowed the observation of the small molecule BMS-386150 bound to different HIV strains

h3: Co-Crystal Structures Show Potential Additional Functional Group

h3._: Structural "Freezing" by Temsavir binding
